channel.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
channel.description:
well, iv burned out another board and chip so i guess its time to make a new one! was wondering if you guys could take a look over my system and tell em what you think.. i still cannot decide if i should use 24gb of ram @ 1600mhz or 12gb of ram at 2000mhz+ i run alot of VM's at the same time among other things so i do need the 24gb but i was wondering would the 12gb run better since its faster? (been think of getting 2x 12gb kits of ram but i dont think ill get the 2000mhz speed?)
anyway here is my list of components, any help or advice is welcomed!
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/intel-core-i7-990x-extreme-s-1366-gulftown-six-core-346ghz-qpi-64gt-s-12mb-cache-26x-ratio-130w-reta
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/corsair-600t-graphite-series-limited-edition-white-mid-tower-gaming-case-with-side-window-w-o-psu
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/3gb-evga-gtx-580-hydro-copper-2-40nm-4008mhz-gddr5-gpu-772mhz-shader-1544mhz-512-cores-mhdmi-plusfre
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/120gb-corsair-force-series-gt-sata-iii-ssd-sandforce-sf2200-read-555mb-s-write-515mb-s-85k-iops
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/asus-rampage-iii-extreme-intel-x58-s-1366-ddr3-sata-iii-6gb-s-sata-raid-pcie-20-(x16)-atx (was looking at the Gigabite G1 assassin?)
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/12gb-(3x4gb)-corsair-ddr3-dominator-gt-pc3-16000-(2000)-unbuffered-9-10-9-27-dhx-xmp-df-165v
^^^^ 12gb 2kmhz could go single or double kit^^^^^
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/24gb-(6x4gb)-corsair-dominator-ddr3-pc3-12800(1600)-nonecc-unbuffered-cas-9-9-9-24-dhx-df-165v
^^^^ 24gb kit^^^^^^
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/1250w-psu-ocz-technology-zx-series-zx1250w-modular-92-eff-80-plus-gold-sli-crossfire-eps-12v-quiet-f
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/ek-kit-h3o-supreme-lt-360-intel-cpu-water-cooling-kit-using-10mm-fitting

item.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
item.dc:creator: @N00b1 N00b1
item.description:
@N00b1 wrote:

[quote=“tL, post:8, topic:414440”][quote author=Brolapse link=topic=516403.msg3749316#msg3749316 date=1315911580]

Buying an enthusiast/extreme intel cpu at this time is a bad move considering ivy bridge extreme is just around the corner.

Isn’t it always the case that it’s a bad idea to buy X processor because the newer better one is “just around the corner”? There has to be literally less than 2-3 months a year in which you can buy a processor without someone going “oh you might as well wait for the newer one”. In reality it seems to me like a waste of time to wait.
[/quote]

No. Because this current chipset has been out for like, nearly three years now. It’s ending it’s life. It isn’t as if this individual line of CPUs Intel has gets refreshed every few months, it’s often much longer. They’ll add new CPUs to them, discontinue others, but they’ll keep this enthusiast/workstation level chipset out for a few years.

I agree with Spel, it’d be silly to buy into this individual platform now - it’s old.[/quote]

yeah its true, iv been looking around a bit more and the sandybridge-e is out in november. thats the new LGA2011. was thing of getting a i72600k and a board, until the new socket is out, after, its only a few months right!

Read full topic
item.source: Building a new piece of shit :D

item.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“Brolapse, post:7, topic:414440”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=516403.msg3749263#msg3749263 date=1315896427]
Buying an enthusiast/extreme intel cpu at this time is a bad move considering ivy bridge extreme is just around the corner.
[/quote]
Isn’t it always the case that it’s a bad idea to buy X processor because the newer better one is “just around the corner”? There has to be literally less than 2-3 months a year in which you can buy a processor without someone going “oh you might as well wait for the newer one”. In reality it seems to me like a waste of time to wait.[/quote]

No. Because this current chipset has been out for like, nearly three years now. It’s ending it’s life. It isn’t as if this individual line of CPUs Intel has gets refreshed every few months, it’s often much longer. They’ll add new CPUs to them, discontinue others, but they’ll keep this enthusiast/workstation level chipset out for a few years.

I agree with Spel, it’d be silly to buy into this individual platform now - it’s old.

Read full topic
item.source: Building a new piece of shit :D

item.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Speljohan:

Buying an enthusiast/extreme intel cpu at this time is a bad move considering ivy bridge extreme is just around the corner.

Isn’t it always the case that it’s a bad idea to buy X processor because the newer better one is “just around the corner”? There has to be literally less than 2-3 months a year in which you can buy a processor without someone going “oh you might as well wait for the newer one”. In reality it seems to me like a waste of time to wait.

Read full topic
item.source: Building a new piece of shit :D

item.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
item.dc:creator: @vortex vortex
item.description:
@vortex wrote:

Aren’t you going to buy a normal HDD? With only just the SSD, you install two games and bam, it’s full.

Read full topic
item.source: Building a new piece of shit :D

item.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

Buying an enthusiast/extreme intel cpu at this time is a bad move considering ivy bridge extreme is just around the corner.

Also, ram amount > ram speed for what you want. The speed makes very little difference when it’s above 1ghz.

EDIT: Oh, and water cooling is PROBABLY a bad idea. There are plenty of fan solutions that are both cheaper and more silent.

Read full topic
item.source: Building a new piece of shit :D

item.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

For doing things like running multiple VMs, you would end up with faster over-all performance by getting a slower CPU with more cores (or multiple CPUs), so don’t they make 8-core or more CPUs you could look at?

Also, after you get it up and running, look into CPU-pinning.

Read full topic
item.source: Building a new piece of shit :D

item.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
item.dc:creator: @N00b1 N00b1
item.description:
@N00b1 wrote:

Thanks for the advice fat cookies! i took a look at the xeon’s i even considered the sr2 (ohh that thing looks sweet). in the end i chose the 990x because i burned out my 860 and my mobo (shit heatsink and shit board - my fault) but the 860 was running 90%+ all the time. i develop games, and i found i could run the editor and one VM with 90%+ load but when it came to compile everything needed to be shut down and compile times where embarrassing. plus i do love to play my games.

Read full topic
item.source: Building a new piece of shit :D

item.title: Building a new piece of shit :D
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I understand the need for a lot of RAM as multiple VM’s obviously do need it, however I think that processor is a bit overkill, I’m sure the standard 980 is insanely fast as is the other i7 processors. You should think about getting the standard one as it is almost half the price… For the price of the cpu you’ve chosen you could even consider getting a hex core xeon such as:
http://www.scan.co.uk/products/intel-xeon-x5650-s-1366-westmere-six-core-266ghz-64gt-s-qpi-12mb-cache-95w-retail
The lower clock speed means you’ll save elecricity but will still get performance!

Read full topic
item.source: Building a new piece of shit :D
